awd_titl_txt: Identifying and Addressing Mathematical Difficulties in Introductory Physics Courses
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is a systematic effort to identify and address mathematics-related learning issues in introductory physics courses. The courses include algebra- and calculus-based general physics. The model emphasizes small-group, active student problem-solving using research-based curricular materials, in which students express and reflect on their thinking verbally and in writing.  The project is to establish a basis for the design and development of new strategies for improving student engagement in introductory physics, which it is hoped will improve student retention in physics.  

Project findings and products contribute substantially to the body of research and of evidence-based instructional materials available for undergraduate physics courses.  These will be a resource for other researchers and curriculum developers. The model incorporates identification and analysis of specific student mathematical difficulties. Use of the materials in targeted instruction will be followed by assessment of student learning. This analysis will be used to develop tightly focused instructional materials.

por.por_cntn:
We have investigated mathematical difficulties encountered by university students who are enrolled in introductory physics courses. Over a three-year period, we have administered over 4000 written diagnostic tests in dozens of different algebra- and calculus-based physics courses on two different campuses at Arizona State University, and carried out 75 individual problem-solving interviews. We found that regardless of course (i.e., algebra- or calculus-based), campus, or semester (spring or fall), that (1) difficulties with basic mathematical operations (algebra, trigonometry, graphing, geometry) are widespread, with average error rates ranging from 20-70%; (2)  performance on algebra problems using symbols for constant coefficients is consistently and significantly worse than on problems using numerical coefficients; and (3) during problem-solving interviews, students self-correct approximately 50% of all errors with only minimal prompting. Additional analysis suggested that students enrolled in higher-performing courses may demonstrate a larger proportion of errors that are "careless" (rather than due to difficulties with fundamental mathematical operations), when compared to students in lower-performing courses. We have begun work on an online instructional tool to aid students in addressing these difficulties.

Intellectual Merit: We utilized a very large sample size (over 4000 students), a wide variety of courses (both first- and second-semesters of both algebra- and calculus-based courses), and a diversity of student populations (enrolled at two different campuses of Arizona State University, representing students with distinctly different majors and previous background). We repeated our test administrations over a three-year (six-semester) period. Our findings nonetheless displayed very consistent patterns that were clear and unambiguous, despite being somewhat unexpected. Plans are underway to seek confirmation of our results at other universities.

Broader Impacts: The difficulties we identified can potentially have a significant negative impact on students' performance in "gatekeeper" introductory physics courses, thus hampering their academic progress. Our findings disclosed a level of student difficulties that was unanticipated by the broader community of physics educators, and yet one that resonated and was consistent with anecdotal experiences of many individuals in that community. This led them to be open and receptive to our reported findings, and very interested in possible future instructional approaches that might be developed to address the difficulties.
